newsitem.title: USA: Appeal notice filed in Florida Bucs bonds case.
newsitem.headline: Appeal notice filed in Florida Bucs bonds case.

text.p: Former Tampa Mayor Bill Poe has filed a notice that he plans to appeal to the Florida Supreme Court to block a $204.5 million bond issue for the National Football League Tampa Bay Buccaneers' new stadium.

Poe's attorney, Chris Bentley, filed the notice Monday in Hillsborough County Circuit Court in Tampa, an aide said. The state Supreme Court clerk in Tallahassee said the formal appeal had not yet been filed Tuesday, so no hearing was scheduled.
Poe argued that the stadium plan would unconstitutionally use taxpayer money for a project that would mainly benefit the private, for-profit football team.

Last week, Hillsborough County Circuit Judge Sam Pendino refused to validate the bond issue. He said a lease provision giving the Bucs the first $2 million in non-Bucs revenues from the stadium made the project one primarily for private gain.

The ruling was a victory for Poe. But he plans to appeal to the state supreme court because Pendino said he would validate the bond issue, if the team renegotiated its lease with Hillsborough County, the City of Tampa and the Tampa Sports Authority by April 4.

The authority would issue the revenue bonds, with debt service paid from sales taxes. Hillsborough County voters approved a one-cent sales tax hike in September for schools, public safety and the stadium.
